articles.headline: A High-End Property Collapse in Singapore
articles.snippet: The government’s plan to stall a property boom that had become a symbol of inequality has worked only too well.
articles.abstract: The government’s plan to stall a property boom that had become a symbol of inequality has worked only too well.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Lamborghinis, Porsches and Bentleys fill the driveways of multimillion-dollar villas in Sentosa Cove. Yachts line the 400-berth marina nearby. A number of homes have guardhouses for security.

articles.headline: Judge Hears Arguments Over G.M.’s Exposure to Recall Suits
articles.snippet: A federal judge will determine if a provision of the company’s July 2009 bankruptcy agreement shields it from lawsuits over a defective ignition switch.
articles.abstract: A federal judge will determine if a provision of the company’s July 2009 bankruptcy agreement shields it from lawsuits over a defective ignition switch.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fraught summer of 2009, the federal bankruptcy judge Robert E. Gerber proved to be a crucial figure in General Motors’ struggle for survival. With the economy in deep recession and the once-dominant automaker bleeding red ink, he presided over a fast-track bankruptcy process that allowed G.M. to remake itself — with the help of $49 billion from federal taxpayers — as a new company free of onerous liabilities.

articles.headline: Re-election Bid Offers Test of Mayor’s Appeal to ‘Two Chicagos’
articles.snippet: Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s incumbent mayor, is viewed as the front-runner for re-election next week, but a worry for his campaign is how he will do with black voters.
articles.abstract: Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s incumbent mayor, is viewed as the front-runner for re-election next week, but a worry for his campaign is how he will do with black voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In some of this city’s predominantly black neighborhoods on the South Side, Rahm Emanuel was not well known when he swept into the mayor’s office in 2011. After all, he had been a congressman from the other, mostly white side of town. But most voters knew that President Obama, himself a South Sider, had trusted him to be White House chief of staff, and that backing went a long way. Mr. Emanuel won every majority black ward in the city.

articles.headline: The Promise and Failure of Community Colleges
articles.snippet: President Obama’s offer of a full ride to community college should increase enrollment, but its success will depend more on how many students graduate.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s offer of a full ride to community college should increase enrollment, but its success will depend more on how many students graduate.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are two critical things to know about community colleges.

articles.headline: As Rivals Falter, India’s Economy Is Surging Ahead
articles.snippet: Long considered a laggard, India is seeing a lift in its stock market as multinational companies look to expand operations there or start new ones.
articles.abstract: Long considered a laggard, India is seeing a lift in its stock market as multinational companies look to expand operations there or start new ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: SRIPERUMBUDUR, India — China’s economy is slowing. Brazil is struggling as commodity prices plunge. Russia, facing Western sanctions and weak oil revenue, is headed into a recession.

articles.headline: Facing Suits, a Nursing Home in California Seeks Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Plaintiffs’ lawyers criticize the move as a maneuver to avoid what could be catastrophic legal verdicts in lawsuits over the quality of care.
articles.abstract: Plaintiffs’ lawyers criticize the move as a maneuver to avoid what could be catastrophic legal verdicts in lawsuits over the quality of care.
articles.lead_paragraph: A California nursing home fined by the state for substandard care and facing multiple lawsuits by patients and their families has taken the extreme measure of filing for bankruptcy protection in the face of millions of dollars in potential payouts.

articles.headline: Gaps in France’s Surveillance Are Clear; Solutions Aren’t
articles.snippet: The nation chose to stop monitoring Saïd and Chérif Kouachi before they struck Charlie Hebdo. But there is no consensus on what lessons to learn.
articles.abstract: The nation chose to stop monitoring Saïd and Chérif Kouachi before they struck Charlie Hebdo. But there is no consensus on what lessons to learn.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last June, Patrick Calvar, the head of France’s domestic intelligence service, faced a decision: continue surveillance on a French Islamist who had been viewed as a potential threat for a decade, or shift limited resources to help monitor a swelling new generation of fighters returning from Syria.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Coming Soon: Celebrity Web Networks From the Media Company Whalerock
articles.snippet: A media company sees a future in cutting out the middleman and giving celebrities like the Kardashians and Tyler, the Creator their own personal channels via the web and mobile app.
articles.abstract: A media company sees a future in cutting out the middleman and giving celebrities like the Kardashians and Tyler, the Creator their own personal channels via the web and mobile app.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — An under-the-radar media company here called Whalerock could become a threat to the entertainment establishment.

articles.headline: Ukrainian Soldiers’ Retreat From Eastern Town Raises Doubt for Truce
articles.snippet: President Petro O. Poroshenko sought to cast the retreat from the strategic town in a positive light, but it was clearly a devastating defeat at the hands of the separatists.
articles.abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko sought to cast the retreat from the strategic town in a positive light, but it was clearly a devastating defeat at the hands of the separatists.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine — Ukrainian soldiers were forced to fight their way out of the embattled town of Debaltseve in the early hours of Wednesday, casting further doubt on the credibility of a days-old cease-fire and eroding the promise of ending a war in Europe that has killed more than 5,000 people.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: ‘Magnificent Obsessions’ Show at the Barbican Explores Portraits of the Artist as Collector
articles.snippet: An exhibition at the Barbican Art Gallery in London, “Magnificent Obsessions: The Artist as Collector,” displays an array of what creative minds gather and keep.
articles.abstract: An exhibition at the Barbican Art Gallery in London, “Magnificent Obsessions: The Artist as Collector,” displays an array of what creative minds gather and keep.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Their works may be coveted by collectors, but artists often have a predilection for building eccentric collections of their own. Many like to pick up bric-a-brac from curiosity shops, market stalls and auction houses. Predictably enough, Damien Hirst owns skulls and stuffed animals. Less widely known is that Peter Blake hoards vintage shop signs, while Martin Parr boasts an impressive collection of Soviet souvenirs.

articles.headline: Fox Searchlight Outshines Rivals in Oscar Hunt
articles.snippet: With two films up for best picture at the Academy Awards, the studio is on a winning streak of producing blockbusters with art house appeal.
articles.abstract: With two films up for best picture at the Academy Awards, the studio is on a winning streak of producing blockbusters with art house appeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At the Academy Awards on Sunday, Fox Searchlight Pictures will have two films in the running for top honors: Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” and Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel.”

articles.headline: Photoshop at 25: A Thriving Chameleon Adapts to an Instagram World
articles.snippet: Adobe, which introduced the image-editing program in 1990, has moved to a less expensive subscription-based model in an effort to democratize access.
articles.abstract: Adobe, which introduced the image-editing program in 1990, has moved to a less expensive subscription-based model in an effort to democratize access.
articles.lead_paragraph: The history of digital technology is full of innovations that are praised for having changed the world: the Mac, Microsoft Windows, the Netscape Navigator browser, the iPod and countless others. Then there are the many products that changed the world and were suddenly overtaken by some newer, supposedly better thing: the Mac, Microsoft Windows, Netscape Navigator, the iPod and countless others.

articles.headline: Obama Urges Global United Front Against Extremist Groups Like ISIS
articles.snippet: The president outlined his administration’s efforts to counter what he called “violent extremism” in a speech to law enforcement, community and religious leaders.
articles.abstract: The president outlined his administration’s efforts to counter what he called “violent extremism” in a speech to law enforcement, community and religious leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama called on Americans and more than 60 nations on Wednesday to join the fight against violent extremism, saying they had to counter the ideology of the Islamic State and other groups making increasingly sophisticated appeals to young people around the world.

articles.headline: A Bid for Guns on Campuses to Deter Rape
articles.snippet: As lawmakers in 10 states push for so-called campus carry laws, an argument is taking shape: Arming female students will help reduce sexual assault.
articles.abstract: As lawmakers in 10 states push for so-called campus carry laws, an argument is taking shape: Arming female students will help reduce sexual assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: As gun rights advocates push to legalize firearms on college campuses, an argument is taking shape: Arming female students will help reduce sexual assaults.
